physDesc.p: [The letter consists of five sheets of paper with typewriting on both sides of the first four and on one side of the fifth. The first sheet has a hole punched at the bottom near the center, but the last four have the same size hole punched on the top instead. On the first page, a small amount of text is cut off on the left side but it does not interrupt the comprehension of the letter. At the top of each sheet (every other page) except the first, there is a hand-written page number in the center top.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I received two very nice letters from you and the first pamphlet of the translations, just before I left Dublin. This one is in no sense to be an answer to those letters. That must wait. It is just a little business letter, written off in a hurry, because I am so frightfully busy. I am on the final proof of the “Six French Poets.” and the publishers put “Rush” on every set of proofs they send me. I am so sick of tracking mistakes down long pages of print that I do not know what to do, but the 132 translations are done, thank goodness, and it is only a case of rushing to get everything off my hands. To my intense astonishment Mr. Macmillan in London has bought one hundred copies. Why, I cannot imagine, as I did not suppose his experience with “Sword Blades” had endeared me to him. But such is the fact, and I only hope the poor man will be justified.

I have not heard a word from you as to whether or not you liked my article on you in the September Little Review. I do hope you did, because I only said what I believed to be the absolute truth, but still there are such a lot of knocks on this business, and so little comfort, that I should like a lot to feel that I had given you a momentary pleasure.

I have just taken upon myself to give Braithwaite permission to include a couple of Hilda’s poems which appeared in our Anthology in his “Anthology of American Magazine Verse.” I suspect you won’t like the book, because Braithwaite is no great shakes as to judgement, and to my mind his past Anthologies (it is an annual affair) have been beneath contempt. But he is anxious to learn, and very enthusiastic, and I think I have had considerable influence on him during this last year, though not nearly as much as I wish I had. One has to go slowly and tactfully in trying to affect a person’s ideas, and he had not the education to be affected very far. All of this is for your private consumption – yours and Hilda’s – and please do not pass it on, even to Flint, for the man has been as white as snow to me, and has helped us a good deal. There is one advantage about his Anthology – it sells enormously. All the schools buy it, and the sale runs up into 5000 or 6000 somewhere. I will send you a copy of this one as soon as it comes out. I knew he could not have you, as you are an English-man, so I thought it would be all right to give him permission for Hilda’s things. Nobody ever refuses permission to anything, because it is a wonderful way to get before the public. Now here is the difficulty as far as I am concerned. You say you would like to have “Patterns” in our new Anthology, but to my intense astonishment Braithwaite has informed me that he has taken “Patterns” for his Anthology. Of course, it being in his Anthology does not in the least preclude it from being in ours, but the only thing is, the public may get tired of seeing the same poem repeated too many times. I should have much preferred to have had it in our Anthology, but Braithwaite had it all in print before he asked my permission, saying with a sweet smile that he knew I would not refuse him.

Fletcher is at the moment in Chicago, and he expects to be here by about the middle of November. As soon as he comes, he and I will go over our poems together, and send you over some things to choose from, and then you can turn down what you don’t like, and so we can gradually get to a position where we are all pleased. Fletcher and I will mark those we send, naming them first, second and third choice, and then if you turn down the first and pitch on the second, we will take the second, and so on, or you can mix them round differently. I suggest that you do this with yours in England. You collect Hilda’s, Flint’s and Lawrence’s and your own, and arrange them in what you think is the best way. Arrange them in the order of your choice, and then send them over to us to agree upon. For above all things, we must keep, on both sides, the democratic freedom of our Anthology. We must all be pleased with the arrangement as we were last year. I will be spokesman for the American group, Fletcher and myself, and you be spokesman for the English group, and then you and I will only have to deal with each other.

It is very generous of you, dear Richard, to offer to have the Anthology turned round and go backward, for the sake of giving me first and you last, but I think that would be a mistake, grateful as I am for the suggestion. I am sure that the best way is to keep our alphabetical order. It gives you a little advantage, I admit, but I think that is the only fair way to do. Whatever advantage you get comes from the accident of having a name beginning with “A”, whereas if we went turn and turn about, the people in the middle might complain that they never had a chance to be first, and they would certainly complain with reason, and to have a different order each time seems unnecessarily laborious.

I have been trying to get hold of Brown, and get at the two poems for our Anthology, but he has taken out his telephone and I have not been able to get in town yet, but I hope to round him up this week.

Now as to your suggestion that we print one poem each of a few of the younger people, I am very much averse to any such suggestion, and I think I am quoting Fletcher correctly when I say that he is too. Unless there is someone whom it is evident would add greatly to our value if included in the Anthology, I see no advantage in adding anyone to our little group. If we are any good as a group our influence is sure to widen, and to include every young aspirant who has been at all affected by our point of view would make our Anthology unnecessarily jejune. You say yourself that none of the people you know, Clara Shanafelt, Marianne Moore, etc., have seven poems good enough to put in the Anthology. Now a poet who has not seven good poems is still only a tyro. I think as our contract was only for three years, it would be much better for us to stay just as we are for 1916 and 1917. We shall confuse the public less that way, and we are more certain to stay as a group and not be confused with the Brunos and Kreymborgs, who, hard-working and energetic young men as they are, hardly seem exactly of our way of thinking.

By the way, I see that you are to have some poems in November “Others.” I think the best think Kreymborg has published in that paper is Stevens’s “Peter Quince,” but Fletcher writes that he has seen other things of Stevens’s, and they are not any good. This does not at all mean I think Stevens belongs in our group, but merely as a remark. All of which means that if you have no great objection, it would be better for the next two years, while our present contract lasts, for us to keep simply the six of us together who were in the Anthology last year.

By the way, if you see Lawrence, tell him that I am sending him his money order. He changed his address, and I was afraid to send it in the dark, and just as I was on the eve of sending it to you I got a letter from him, and it should reach him very soon, but if you mention having received royalties and he has not got any, he may think I am trying to keep him without any.
If you are really very anxious to include some of the younger people in the Anthology, why, we might talk it over some more, but I think it would [be] a little better not to.

I have just heard of the death of Remy de Gourmont, which must be a dreadful blow to you. I am extremely sorry, and I am afraid he must have suffered terribly before his death. He was so kind to me in sending me his picture for the book, with such pleasant words of encouragement, and one of the things I was looking forward to was sending it to him. I feel we have all lost our best friend, and find myself feeling a very personal loss, although I never saw him.

I enclose money order to pay for my ten sets of the translations. I like them so much, and am giving them round to various people. I am going to New York as soon as I have finished my book, and am going to see if I can get Gomme to take them on and sell them for you.

div.note: Amy Lowell, "Richard Aldington's Poetry," The Little Review, September, 1915 (Vol. 2, No. 6), 11-16.
